Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: A platform for biological information integration and knowledge discovery
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to help researchers to identify novel scientific hypotheses and make discoveries by harnessing the power of big data being generated in biological and biomedical fields. It is well known that big data have significant commercial potential, but also present some new challenges. For example, unstructured information in scientific publications needs to be converted to a structured form. This task is important for organizing existing scientific discoveries in a structured format for downstream applications. In addition, heterogeneous, large volume biological information needs to be integrated into a data structure effective for knowledge discovery. For example, integrating disease-protein relationships and protein-small molecule relationships will likely help us to identify small molecule drugs for treating diseases. Integrating the research findings from different sources is essential for understanding the big picture of biological systems. An effective integration will open the doors to important applications with commercial potential, such as drug repurposing and drug side effect prediction.

This project aims to develop three commercial products. The first product is a software tool for bio-entity relationship extraction based on a novel, proprietary method for extracting bio-entity relationships from unstructured texts. The second product is a commercial database for context-specific molecular interaction information based on the integrated molecular interaction database (IMID) developed previously. IMID integrates multiple types of bio-entity relationships with versatile query functions. A commercial version of IMID will be built using updated information with additional functionalities. The third product is a platform for biological information integration and data mining with applications in drug repurposing and drug side effect prediction. Integrated bio-entity network (IBN) is a novel data structure for biological information integration and data mining. It offers some unique advantages compared to existing systems/approaches. Knowledge discovery tools based on IBN will facilitate biologists to search direct and indirect bio-entity relationships effectively. Two drug related data mining applications will be built: Drug repurposing search and drug side effect prediction, which utilize the unique advantage of IBN in identification of dysregulated pathways and subnetworks between two biological conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

This proposal aimed to develop  a platform for the integration and mining of high-throughput genomics data. We first focused on oncology data as a proof of concept. We have integrated several types of high-throughput data at TCGA (the Cancer Genome Atlas) and GEO (gene expression Omnibus) into a relational database with versatile query functions. We have also developed advanced data analytics tools to analyze user provided data in the context of existing knowledge and data, which often have large volumes and heterogeneous forms. Proprietary technologies have been developed to strengthen the competitive advantage of our products.

Intellectual Merit

In the STTR phase I project, we have developed several noval products/technologies:

1. A software for automatic bio-entity relationship extraction

We implemented the information extraction method as a tool on our BioKDE (Biomedical Knowledge Discovery Engine) platform. The patent for the method has been issued in Nov 2014. The method extract relationships between biological terms in published literature. The biological terms include, but not limited to, proteins, genes, diseases, pathways, drugs and small molecule names.

2. A database for integrated molecular interactions

We implemented a database with integrated molecular interaction information on BioKDE platform. The data was integrated from several public databases and also include information extracted from literature. The queried data can be conveniently incorporated as part of an analysis pipeline on BioKDE.

3. A platform for accelerating biomedical discovery with big data - BioKDE: Biomedical Knowledge Discovery Engine

We implemented the BioKDE platform based on an open source framework, galaxy project. We integrated data from both the cancer genome atlas (TCGA) and gene expression omnibus (GEO) and implemented query interfaces as tools on BioKDE. We implemented a set of statistical and graphics tools on BioKDE. In addition, we implemented a few tools developed by ourselves, such as the network structure inference tool, the oncology information query tool, etc.

4. A new method for cross-platform normalization

A common problem in genomics data integration is combining data generated from different experimental platforms. We have developed a new method for tackling this problem. Using benchmark data, we show our method performs better than the state-of-the-art method. We plan to apply for a patent for this method, which will further strengthen our IP portfolio.

5. An integrative genomic analysis (IGA) tool for comparison of genomics profiles that integrate existing data and knowledge of biological networks

Most of current methods for comparing genomics profiles generate a list of genes or candidates, which can contain potentially a large number of false positives. Putting this list of genes into the known biological networks allows researchers to understand better the functional implications of the results. Using statistics calculated from exiting data can also help researchers to identify biological significant calls and filter out those only with statistical significance. The tool was called Integrative Genomic Analysis (IGA) in an earlier version.

6. Scientific discoveries made using integrated data and tools at BioKDE

We have made a few dozen discoveries in cancer related topics. These discoveries are available as interactive reports on our website. We plan to use these discoveries as a novel channel to reach out to our target customers and build reputation and brand recognition.

 

The products described above can be found at our website, www.insilicom.com. 

 

Broader/Commercial Impact
